title: What do staff report about feeling pressured to work when unwell and how has this changed?
analysis_commentary:
In 2009, just over one fifth of staff reported that they felt pressure to attend work when feeling unwell in the previous three months. Subsequently, up to 2012 there was a year-on-year increase in staff reporting feeling pressure to work when feeling unwell, rising to 27% in 2012. In 2013, a quarter of all staff reported that they felt pressure to attend work when feeling unwell, which is still greater than when the data was first collected in 2009 but this has decreased by 2 percentage points from 2012.

Ambulance trust staff consistently reported feeling more pressure to attend work when feeling unwell in the previous three months when compared to acute, mental health and learning disabilities, and community trusts.
data_source: Department of Health, Survey of NHS Staff
